docs.snippet: Foday Sankoh, the rebel leader who has been held in prison for nearly two years, was taken to court and charged with murder, a charge that could lead to the death penalty, according to Justice Minister Solomon Berewa. The government could no longe...
docs.lead_paragraph: Foday Sankoh, the rebel leader who has been held in prison for nearly two years, was taken to court and charged with murder, a charge that could lead to the death penalty, according to Justice Minister Solomon Berewa. The government could no longer hold Mr. Sankoh and 71 other members of the Revolutionary United Front without filing charges because a state of emergency was lifted last week, Mr. Berewa said. The rebels killed and mutilated thousands of civilians in the civil war, which they and the government have declared over. Elections are set for May. Norimitsu Onishi (NYT)
docs.abstract: Sierra Leone charges rebel leader Foday Sankoh with murder for his role during civil war; photo (S)

headline.main: World Briefing | Africa: Sierra Leone: Rebel Leader Charged

docs.snippet: At least a dozen members of militant groups were killed by Indian forces in Kashmir in the last two days, the authorities said. Most had been trying to cross the line that separates the Pakistani- and Indian-controlled parts of the territory. The ...
docs.lead_paragraph: At least a dozen members of militant groups were killed by Indian forces in Kashmir in the last two days, the authorities said. Most had been trying to cross the line that separates the Pakistani- and Indian-controlled parts of the territory. The Indian government has said that all guerrilla infiltration must cease before it reduces its heavy deployment in the region. Barry Bearak (NYT)
docs.abstract: Indian authorities say their forces in Kashmir killed dozen members of militant groups trying to cross line separating Pakistani- and Indian-controlled parts of territory (S)

headline.main: World Briefing | Asia: India: Violence In Kashmir

docs.snippet: A global ban on child soldiers has gone into effect, the United Nations said. The treaty bars recruitment of children under 18 by armies and militias, a practice that affects an estimated 300,000 children. Since the pact was approved in May 2000 b...
docs.lead_paragraph: A global ban on child soldiers has gone into effect, the United Nations said. The treaty bars recruitment of children under 18 by armies and militias, a practice that affects an estimated 300,000 children. Since the pact was approved in May 2000 by the General Assembly, 96 countries have signed it and 14 countries have ratified it. The United States, which allows voluntary enlistment at 17, has not yet ratified the treaty. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)
docs.abstract: UN says global ban on child soldiers has gone into effect; treaty bars recruitment of children under 18 by armies and militias, practice that affects estimated 300,000 children (S)

headline.main: World Briefing | World: Ban On Young Soldiers

docs.snippet: The specter of Sept. 11 will hover over New Year's celebrations across America tonight. With 7,500 police officers on watch, 500,000 revelers are expected to crowd into Times Square for fireworks, music and the ball-drop spectacle. Bells will ring...
docs.lead_paragraph: The specter of Sept. 11 will hover over New Year's celebrations across America tonight. With 7,500 police officers on watch, 500,000 revelers are expected to crowd into Times Square for fireworks, music and the ball-drop spectacle. Bells will ring across town for the 3,000 victims. Thousands remembered the victims at ground zero yesterday as New York opened its official viewing stand. The crowds braved frigid winds and six-block lines for a glimpse of devastation. They sobbed, prayed, whispered, gawked and took snapshots. And halfway around the world, the war slogged on.
docs.abstract: Overview of day's events in war against terror (M)

headline.kicker: A NATION CHALLENGED: AN OVERVIEW: DEC. 30, 2001

docs.snippet: Doctors Without Borders, the medical charity, called today for the United Nations to take measures to improve the deteriorating conditions for 180,000 Chechen refugees spending their third winter homeless.    The charity said in a statement that i...
docs.lead_paragraph: Doctors Without Borders, the medical charity, called today for the United Nations to take measures to improve the deteriorating conditions for 180,000 Chechen refugees spending their third winter homeless. The charity said in a statement that it had presented its appeal to the United Nations high commissioner for refugees, Ruud Lubbers, who visited camps near Chechnya on a one-day trip to the region.
docs.abstract: Doctors Without Borders, medical charity, calls for United Nations to take measures to improve deteriorating conditions for 180,000 Chechen refugees spending their third winter homeless; says more than 60,000 of them are still living in tents or vacant school and factory buildings, and that plight of displaced population has lost attention of international community; Russia has reduced much of Chechnya to rubble in two wars since 1994 (M)

headline.main: Better Conditions Sought for Chechen Refugees

docs.snippet: Slobodan Milosevic, the former Yugoslav president, has the flu and his trial was suspended for three days, according to the war crimes tribunal. Richard May, the presiding judge, said the trial could not continue without Mr. Milosevic because he i...
docs.lead_paragraph: Slobodan Milosevic, the former Yugoslav president, has the flu and his trial was suspended for three days, according to the war crimes tribunal. Richard May, the presiding judge, said the trial could not continue without Mr. Milosevic because he is defending himself. The trial, which began five weeks ago, has heard 19 prosecution witnesses and Mr. Milosevic has personally cross-examined most of them. Marlise Simons (NYT)
docs.abstract: War crimes trial of former Yugoslav president Slobodan Milosevic is suspended for three days while he recovers from flu (S)

headline.main: World Briefing | Europe: The Hague: Milosevic Is Ill

docs.snippet: An Albanian doctor, describing the war in Kosovo in 1999, recounted in court today how he watched through his window as the Serbian police executed two of his relatives.    Then he heard gunshots as the police killed four more people in a house ne...
docs.lead_paragraph: An Albanian doctor, describing the war in Kosovo in 1999, recounted in court today how he watched through his window as the Serbian police executed two of his relatives. Then he heard gunshots as the police killed four more people in a house nearby, and he watched as they set a building on fire and placed all the bodies there to be immolated along with it.
docs.abstract: Albanian doctor testifies at war crimes trial of Slobodan Milosevic; describes war in Kosovo in 1999 and recounts how he watched through window as Serbian police executed two of his relatives, then four more people in house nearby, then set building on fire and placed bodies there to be immolated along with it; Milosevic, in cross-examining doctor, tries to make NATO airstrikes the issue; he has seized every opportunity to blame NATO and Albanian guerrillas for killings in Kosovo; legal experts point out that alleging guilt of others may not help Milosevic rebut specific allegations against forces under his command; prosecutors intend to call dozens of eyewitnesses like Albanian doctor (M)

headline.main: Killings in Kosovo Are Described at War Trial

docs.snippet: The government is sending more troops to fight rebels in the north after losing control of an important border town, a military official said. The fighting is part of a power struggle in the diamond-rich region at the junction of Liberia, Sierra L...
docs.lead_paragraph: The government is sending more troops to fight rebels in the north after losing control of an important border town, a military official said. The fighting is part of a power struggle in the diamond-rich region at the junction of Liberia, Sierra Leone and Guinea. Rebels of Liberians United for Reconciliation and Democracy are seeking to oust President Charles Taylor. Fighting increased last month and has since left at least 100 dead. The official said government troops had lost control of Kolahun, a town near the border with Sierra Leone and a former rebel base. The United Nations Security Council has imposed sanctions on Liberia, accusing Mr. Taylor of fostering a guns-for-diamonds operation that has fueled civil war in Sierra Leone.
docs.abstract: Liberia reportedly is sending more troops to fight rebels in north after losing control of Kolahun, town near Sierra Leone border and former rebel base; fighting is part of power sturggle in diamond-rich region at junction of Liberia, Sierra Leone and Guinea; map (S)

headline.main: World Briefing | Africa: Liberia: Fighting Grows In Diamond Area

docs.snippet: Slobodan Milosevic vented his anger in war crimes court today, saying his only goal during the Balkans war had been to ''achieve peace'' and asking the United Nations tribunal to free him until his trial begins in two weeks.    Mr. Milosevic, the ...
docs.lead_paragraph: Slobodan Milosevic vented his anger in war crimes court today, saying his only goal during the Balkans war had been to ''achieve peace'' and asking the United Nations tribunal to free him until his trial begins in two weeks. Mr. Milosevic, the former Yugoslav president, appeared before a five-member appeals panel as it heard a motion requesting that the three indictments against him be heard in a single trial. He asked the panel to order his release, promising to return for a ''battle I will not miss'' when prosecutors present their case against him on Feb. 12. He was allowed to rail for 30 minutes against perceived injustices.
docs.abstract: Slobodan Milosevic, former Yugoslav president, vents his anger in war crimes court in The Hague, saying his only goal during Balkans war was to 'achieve peace' and asking United Nations tribunal to free him until his trial begins in two weeks; he is accused of carrying out crimes against humanity during almost 10 years of rule; he calls himself victim of crimes committed against his country; this is first time Milosevic is allowed to speak at length before tribunal, and he seizes opportunity to voice political opinions and anger at prosecution and tribunal; he has refused to accept legal representation (M)

headline.main: Milosevic, Calling Himself a Victim, Asks to Be Freed by Court
